author: admin
title: The number of armed conflicts in the world has reached a record level since 1946 (video)
text:
According to data published by the Norwegian Institute for Research of the World (Prio), the number of armed clashes with the participation of states has reached the maximum over the past 80 years.
In 2024, it was recorded around the world 61 armed confrontation in 36 countries is the highest indicator from the end of World War IIreports Bb.lv.
Analysts of the institute note Sustainable growth in conflicts: in 2022 there were 56 of them, in 2023 â€“ already 59. Last year, 11 were classified among these clashes as full -scale wars.
In the report â€œGlobal Review of Conflicts: Trendsâ€, it is emphasized that two of these wars dominated the number of victims: Russian aggression against Ukraine, which, according to estimates, led to the death of about 76 thousand people, and the escalation of the conflict in the gas sector, which has taken off 26 thousand lives.
The total mortality rate from armed violence in 2023 and 2024 was approximately the same â€“ about 129,000 dead. This indicator significantly exceeds the average values of the last 30 years. Thus, 2024 became the fourth most deadly year since the end of the Cold War in 1989.
Africa â€“ epicenter of violence. Particular attention in the report is paid to internal conflicts in which the national government takes part. The largest number of such cases recorded In Africa â€“ 28 conflictswhich is twice the number of ten years ago. She is following her Asia (17 conflicts), the Middle East (10), Europe (3) and America (2).
Despite the growth of interstate conflicts, the study notes a small reduction in the number of non -state clashes â€“ from 80 in 2023 to 74 in 2024.
Siri Aas Rustad, director of Prio and one of the authors of the report, emphasized:
â€œThe modern world has become much more cruel and fragmented compared to the situation of ten years ago. The closure of borders and the refusal to participate in international processes in the context of global growth of violence can result in catastrophic consequences for millions of people. â€
Some conflicts last for several days, others â€“ years, decades and even centuries. But humanity has not learned how to do without wars â€¦

author: Mary Walrath-Holdridge
title: Kathleen Wilson's Minnesota dentist did 30 procedures at once: lawsuit
text: 20 fillings, 4 root canals, 8 crowns in one visit add up to lawsuit for Minnesota dentist [Mary Walrath-Holdridge](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/12093029002/mary-walrathholdridge/) A Minnesota dentist has become the subject of a malpractice lawsuit after his patient accused him of "disfiguring" her. The civil lawsuit was filed in Hennepin County, Minnesota last week by Kathleen Wilson, who alleged Dr. Kevin Molldrem and [Molldrem Family Dentistry](https://molldremdentistry.com/) caused her significant injury that is still being corrected. According to the suit, Molldrem performed more than 30 producers on Wilson in a single July 2020 visit, doing eight crowns, four root canals and 20 fillings in one go. The lawsuit alleges that the dentist "perform[ed] this work improperly," resulting in pain and suffering, embarrassment, emotional distress, and disfigurement. Molldrem was likewise accused of using improper levels of anesthesia during the procedures and falsifying medical records to cover it up. Treatment called 'inconceivable' â€œIt is inconceivable that Dr. Molldrem could have prepared and placed 8 crowns under these circumstances in the time allotted, not to mention the additional 20 restorations,â€ wrote [Dr. Avrum Goldstein,](https://www.seakexperts.com/members/4827-avrum-r-goldstein) a dentist and expert witness brought on by Wilson's attorney, in an affidavit. Goldstein, who is a faculty member at [NOVA Southeastern University](https://dental.nova.edu/aboutus/faculty/goldstein-avrum%20.html?_gl=1*1kqtqxq*_gcl_au*ODA4NzUxNTA1LjE3MDM3OTc5MjI.), also wrote that Wilson had been correctly diagnosed as having a "rare condition" causing decay in almost all of her teeth, but Mollderm's course of action was not a proper form of treatment. "[Wilsonâ€™s] required a slow, thoughtful, careful and measured response to her disease,â€ he said in his report. â€œTrying to fill every hole in every tooth in her mouth in one visit is not only the antithesis of what was indicated, it is not humanly possible to achieve in an effective or constructive manner.â€ Doctors remove wrong organ from man: [They opened him up to remove his appendix. They mistakenly took out much more, lawsuit says.](/story/news/health/2023/11/07/doctors-accidentally-remove-wrong-organ-surgery/71487292007/) The lawsuit also accused Mollderm of tampering with medical records to falsify the amount of anesthesia that was reportedly used, which in reality was nearly double the standard number of units, according to court paperwork. According to Goldstein, the maximum dose of anesthesia given in three hours should not exceed 490 mg, but Molldrem's records show he gave Wilson 960 mg. â€œAny negative cardiovascular or central nervous system outcomes could be tied to the local anesthetic overdose," he wrote. Wilson said in the suit that she has since had to have the dental work completely redone by other dentists to repair Molldremâ€™s â€œnegligent work," an ongoing process that has caused her to lose income and rack up medical bills on top of enduring pain, suffering and embarrassment. She is seeking more than $50,000 in damages. Wilson's attorney and Molldrem did not immediately respond to request for comment.

author: News 3 Staff
title: chevron-right
text: {p}HEADLINE: Gorgeous weather continues{/p}{p}LOW TODAY: 43{ } { } { } NORMAL LOW: 39{/p}{p}HIGH TODAY: 63{ } { } NORMAL HIGH: 56{/p}{p}Another beauty across southern Nevada as most desert locations climbed above the 60 degree mark for 19th time this December.{/p}{p}Tonight looks great with clear skies and cool temperatures. Look for an overnight low of 43 here in Las Vegas.{/p}{p}Not a whole lot of change for your Friday as high pressure hangs on. If the clouds stay away, we should easily break the 60 degree mark once again tomorrow afternoon, but clouds are expected to increase throughout the afternoon.{/p}{p}A weak area of low pressure will bring a few light showers across southern Nevada late Saturday with the highest chances for free water expected north and west of the valley.{/p}{p}A few hundredths of an inch are possible here in the valley along with 1-2\" of snow in the Spring mountains, mainly above 8,500 feet.{/p}{p}This system will quickly exit on New year's Eve Day with slightly cooler than normal temperatures filtering in just in time for the New Year.{/p}{p}Highs on New Year's Eve and New Year's day should hold in the mid 50s with lows in the lower 40s.{/p}{p}CURRENT SNOWPACK: UPPER COLORADO RIVER BASIN - 73% (106% last year at this time){/p}{p}LAKE MEAD TRACKER: Lake mead is currently at 1067 feet compared to 1043 feet one year ago today.{/p}{p}Total valley rainfall in 2023: 4.58\" (+0.54\" above normal){/p}{p}Total valley rainfall through December 28th, 2022: 2.13\" (-1.90\" below normal){/p}{p}AIR QUALITY - HEALTHY{/p}{p}POLLEN COUNT:{/p}{p}TREES: NONE{/p}{p}MOLD: LOW{/p}{p}GRASS: NONE{/p}{p}WEEDS: LOW{/p}{p}Bill Bellis{br}{/p}{p}Officers shot and killed a suspect when he took out a gun during a foot chase in the central valley Thursday night, according to Las Vegas Metropolitan Police.{/p}{p}The shooting took place in the area of West Charleston Boulevard and South Rancho Boulevard.{/p}{p}Capt. Jeff Clark with LVMPD said officers were notified around 9:27 p.m. about a stolen vehicle on Charleston and spotted it in the drive-thru lane of a fast-food restaurant.{/p}{p}{sd-embed data-embed-type=\"video\" contenteditable=\"false\"}{/sd-embed}{/p}{p}They initiated a high-risk vehicle stop and saw a man run out of the passenger side, he said. Officers chased after the man as he ran east on Charleston into a parking lot.{br}{/p}{p}\"The suspect produced a firearm, at which time multiple officers discharged their firearm, striking the suspect,\" Clark said.{/p}{p}Medical personnel pronounced the suspect dead at the scene. Other officers remained with the car and took the driver into custody, he said.{/p}{p}The shooting remains under investigation.{ }{/p}{p}This marks the 10th officer-involved shooting in LVMPD's jurisdiction for 2023. It also comes less than two days after police{ }{strong}{a href=\"https://news3lv.com/news/local/news-3-confirms-gunman-in-carjacking-police-shooting-in-southwest-las-vegas-valley\" //news3lv.com/news/local/news-3-confirms-gunman-in-carjacking-police-shooting-in-southwest-las-vegas-valley\"}opened fire on Justin Davidson{/a}{/strong} in the southwest valley following a series of vehicle chases and carjackings. The incident left him and two others dead.{/p}{p}The names of the officers involved in Thursday's shooting with be released within 48 hours, in keeping with department policy on police shootings. A full briefing is expected to be held in the coming days as well.{/p}{p}HEADLINE: Gorgeous weather continues{/p}{p}LOW TODAY: 43{ } { } { } NORMAL LOW: 39{/p}{p}HIGH TODAY: 63{ } { } NORMAL HIGH: 56{/p}{p}Another beauty across southern Nevada as most desert locations climbed above the 60 degree mark for 19th time this December.{/p}{p}Tonight looks great with clear skies and cool temperatures. The incident left him and two others dead.{/p}{p}The names of the officers involved in Thursday's shooting with be released within 48 hours, in keeping with department policy on police shootings. A full briefing is expected to be held in the coming days as well.{/p}

author: Jake Pesaruk
title: Experts scrambling to control Ontario's avian flu outbreak as feds stockpile vaccines
text:
With numerous cases of avian influenza appearing in Ontario, experts are scrambling to prevent a potential mass outbreak.
Last December, seven poultry farms in southern Ontario were quarantined due to the pathogenic avian influenza strain(s) HPAI/H5N1, colloquially known as bird flu.
As a byproduct of these contaminations, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) cut off the impacted areas, euthanized all potentially infected poultry, and ensured that all nearby farms were not exposed.
â€œI would say we can call this an exceptional outbreak,â€ the CFIAâ€™s deputy incident commander of avian influenza response, Brian Hamilton, told INsauga.com.
With uncharacteristic outbreaks occurring in Ontario, how safe is the province from an avian flu epidemic among humans?
Yesterday (Feb. 19), the Public Health Agency of Canada (PHAC) released an announcement concerning the procurement of avian flu vaccines to curb what the federal government deemed as an â€œunprecedentedâ€ spread of the virus.
At the time of publication, 500,000 vaccine doses have been secured by the feds, however, only 60 per cent of the available inventory is being sent out to provinces and territories, while the other 40 per cent, will remain under lock and key in the event of a potential pandemic.
A corresponding document from December 2024 by the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) ruled that as long as the country remains in a pre-pandemic state, the distribution of these vaccines will likely prioritize those working near potential contamination scenarios.
These include lab workers, poultry farmers, veterinarians, and wildlife researchers.
However, even with these preventative measures, experts in the field are still preparing for the worst.
â€œI think to be truthful, we are underestimating the power of this virus and the predictability of it. It has proven us wrong too many times and we canâ€™t trust it. It doesnâ€™t respect our politics and it doesnâ€™t respect our borders â€” it certainly doesnâ€™t respect what we think we know about how to mitigate it,â€ Dr. Shayan Sharif, interim VP of research and innovation at Guelph University, told INsauga.com.
Sharif â€” who has an extensive background as a professor of immunology â€” has been following this current strain of avian flu since its emergence in 2020/2021.
Sharif notes that while this current pathogen in Ontario is likely to be traced back to birds from the Maritimes, as the years have progressed, complex factors have entrenched it within the province and, by extension, Canada.
As climate change progresses, Sharif notes that migratory birds are acting erratically, and as a result, lingering where they shouldnâ€™t be and spreading the virus amongst both wild and agricultural avian species.
â€œSo if youâ€™re in cities in Ontario right now, you are likely seeing a lot of Canadian geese or other birds, sometimes, in parks or local bodies of water. Now, is this normal for this time of year? No,â€ says Sharif.
Beyond extended avian layovers in Ontario, the encroaching spring season has Sharif more concerned, as the remainder of migratory birds flooding the province will increase the likelihood of new strains and mutations.
â€œItâ€™s just getting worse and worse. This virus, like any virus, has new mutants and new strains. Most of them are H5N1 but now some are emerging as other types of avian influenza, all with new variants and genotypes,â€ says Sharif. â€œHopefully, it will get better but it still remains a huge cause for concern, as it could potentially adapt itself to human cells.â€
While human transmission of avian influenza remains incredibly rare , last November, a teenage girl in B.C. was infected with the H5N1 strain and hospitalized for several months.
â€œNo one knows how this patient contracted the virus,â€ says Sharif.
While the cause of transmission remains a mystery, official correspondence from the B.C. government indicated that it was likely due to an interaction with infected wild birds, not livestock.
Currently, the U.S. is also struggling with an outbreak of avian influenza, drastically impacting their agricultural economy.
Both the American Bread Belt â€” U.S. agricultural states â€” and Ontario are connected to what is known as the Mississippi Flyway, one of the worldâ€™s largest migratory avian causeways connecting the Arctic to South America.
As a result of this shared exposure, Jianhong Wu, professor and director for Advanced Disaster, Emergency, and Rapid Response Simulations at York University, has been closely monitoring how the virus has been spreading throughout the North American continent.
â€œSouthern Ontario is vulnerable, and the issue of avian flu is going very poorly south of the border. So, I think issues in the U.S. potentially impacting us are inevitable. So the only thing we really can do is increase our surveillance systems and rapid response capabilities,â€ Wu told INsauga.com
Despite the provinceâ€™s vulnerability, Wu did indicate that Ontario (and Canada) are in a much better position to address a potential outbreak, specifically due to lessons learned during COVID-19 â€” a potential throughline to yesterdayâ€™s bulk procurement of vaccines.
However, what separates a potential human pathogen of avian flu from COVID-19 is that its functionality remains in the dark. Add this to the fact that the only recent reference point is one patient from last November, and alarm bells start ringing throughout the scientific community.
â€œThe girl who contracted avian influenza last November was in the hospital for two months,â€ says Sharif. â€œShe was provided with the best possible intensive care that anyone in Canada could get â€” in an order of magnitude more than anyone in Canada could get. Still, she was in the hospital for two months. It was just one patient in the ICU for two months. Could you imagine if we had hundreds or thousands of people taking up hospital beds for two months? What are we going to do?â€
While authorities remain on high alert, those who excel in emergency response procedures like Wu believe that while a potential mass outbreak of avian flu (human or otherwise) can happen anywhere, itâ€™s up to response forces to ensure public safety.
And if they canâ€™t ensure it, at least prepare for what happens next.
â€œIf this is going to happen, itâ€™s going to happen somewhere. What we have to do then, is to slow it down and buy the province and the country some time,â€ he says.
